G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Jurisdiction lies with the **Boston Housing Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3, 6, as this action concerns rights and obligations arising from a residential tenancy located within the City of Boston.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of rented premises is liable for actual and consequential damages, or a minimum of three months’ rent, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 2A**.proposition: Defendant’s decision to withhold lease renewal and label Plaintiff a “problem tenant” after Plaintiff sought official code enforcement further compounded the interference, discouraging Plaintiff from exercising protected rights under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** and **G.L. c. 239, § 2A** (retaliation protections).

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff contacted the **City of Boston Inspectional Services Department** (“ISD”), which inspected the Premises and cited water intrusion and other code violations under the **Massachusetts State Sanitary Code**, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.750, et seq..proposition: Defendant violated this covenant by failing to remedy persistent water intrusion after notice, thereby allowing conditions unfit for human habitation in violation of the **State Sanitary Code**, 105 C.M.R. § 410.750, et seq.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.proposition: The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is also recognized under **Massachusetts common law**, see *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101–02 (1982), and assures that a tenant’s lawful possession will not be substantially disturbed by the landlord’s acts or omissions.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts and ties it to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. In discussing G.L. c. 186, § 14, the court explains the common-law background of “quiet enjoyment,” states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right, and describes it as protection against acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises—i.e., substantial disturbance of lawful possession.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” 385 Mass. at 101–02 (citations omitted).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act constitutes an **“interference with quiet enjoyment”** within the meaning of *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 717–18 (1977), and subsequent cases.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects any strict intent requirement and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, so long as the landlord had the right and ability to control the condition. The reasoning focuses on the landlords’ failure to effectively abate disruptive noise they had the power to control, treating that inaction as a breach sufficient to support constructive eviction and non-liability for rent. This squarely supports using Blackett as authority that a landlord’s failure to act, when they have control over the source of disturbance, can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.raw_text: *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (quiet enjoyment extends to failure to act on known defects).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The proposition states that quiet enjoyment liability extends to a landlord’s failure to act on known defects. Al‑Ziab squarely affirms that principle, explaining that § 14 requires at least negligent conduct and is frequently violated by a landlord’s failure to repair known defects. The court explicitly cites prior cases and reiterates that when a landlord has notice or reason to know of a condition and fails to take appropriate corrective measures, that omission can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ … Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.raw_text: *Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437 Mass. 708 (2002) (breach of covenant may arise from omissions).
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the landlord’s covenant to repair and the covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction, but it does not hold that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment arose here. The court explicitly finds no constructive eviction and resolves the case instead under the newly adopted rule of mutually dependent covenants and a breach of an express covenant to maintain the roof. It therefore does not provide authority that the landlord’s omissions here violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even though it recognizes that omissions can be relevant to constructive eviction analysis.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.relevant_excerpt: “We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. … In this case, the judge found that the landlord failed to adequately maintain the roof, and that, as a consequence, there were periodic leaks during the course of the tenancy. … While the landlord’s breach of his covenant to repair may have made the tenant’s operation less convenient and more expensive, based on the evidence adduced at trial, it did not rise to the level of a constructive eviction.”

*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004) (landlord liability for allowing uninhabitable conditions).
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlord’s failure over nine years to correct a serious ventilation defect (a code violation that produced moisture, odors, and ultimately a fire) constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that such serious, long‑standing defects that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises amount to a ‘serious interference’ with the tenancy, regardless of the landlord’s good‑faith repair efforts. This directly supports using the case as authority that maintaining uninhabitable conditions violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.raw_text: *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (sanitary code violations establish per se breach).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion does not hold that sanitary code violations constitute a per se breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case primarily concerns Chapter 93A liability, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability; the court does not articulate or apply any rule that sanitary code violations automatically establish a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Any discussion of code violations is tied to habitability and damages, not to a per se quiet enjoyment standard.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: "Cases discussing the measure of damages for breach of the common law warranty of habitability hold that the tenant's damages are to be measured by the difference between the value of the dwelling as warranted (the agreed rent may be used as some evidence of this value) and the value of the dwelling unit as it exists in its defective condition. See, e.g., Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 203 (1973); Darmetko v. Boston Housing Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 n. 4 (1979); Wolfberg v. Hunter, supra at 399; McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168, 170-171 (1975)."

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (tenant protected for reporting sanitary code violations).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority stands for tenant protection for reporting sanitary code violations. This opinion does address the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the context of pervasive drug activity and the landlord’s failure to act against nontenants—there is no discussion of sanitary code violations or retaliation/ protection for reporting such violations. Thus, while it is authority on quiet enjoyment, it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 342 Mass. 6.raw_text: *Hemingway v. O’Brien*, 342 Mass. 692 (1961) (recognizing implied obligations of habitability).
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 342 Mass. 6.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment as interpreted in the following authorities, among others:
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 342 Mass. 6.case_name: Murray Realty, Inc. v. Berke Moore Co.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 342 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: This opinion is a tort case about negligent construction damage to neighboring properties during a public works project. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, implied warranty or covenant of habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The holding concerns when a contractor, rather than the Commonwealth, is liable in tort for non-inevitable construction damage, so it does not provide authority for implied habitability obligations or quiet enjoyment doctrines in leases.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 342 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: “This principle ‘presupposes that the public work thus authorized will be executed in a reasonably proper and skilful manner, with a just regard to the rights of private owners of estate. If done otherwise, the damage is not necessarily incident to the accomplishment of the public object, but to the improper and unskilful manner of doing it. Such damage to private property is not warranted by the authority under color of which it is done, and is not justifiable by it.’ Per Shaw, C. J., in Perry v. Worcester, 6 Gray, 544, 547.”
